awd_titl_txt: NSF/SBE-BSF:Integration of kinesthetic and tactile information in perception, action, and learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Simple acts such as opening a jar or lighting a match depend on the ability to grasp objects with different shapes and to apply well-regulated forces and movements in different directions. When we hold a glass of water, the forces applied by the fingers are directed against the surface of the glass, and our brain coordinates these forces to prevent slippage and maintain the orientation of the glass. The planned studies will combine computational methods derived from control engineering and robotics with techniques and theories from neuroscience to understand how the brain controls grip forces when lifting and manipulating objects and how it estimates an object's mechanical properties. The investigations will consider how grasping an object is affected by uncertainties about the object properties (e.g., it's hardness, slipperiness, texture, etc) and how fundamental manipulation skills may be enhanced by artificially augmenting tactile information. The outcomes of these studies will influence several domains including (1) neuroscience (understanding our ability to  control and manipulate objects with our hands); (2) technology (for presenting force information to users of robotic devices such as teleoperation and robot-assisted surgery); and (3) neurorehabilitation (for developing intelligent robotic prostheses and new exercises to promote the recovery of lost manual skills). These studies will establish a collaborative interaction between scientists in the United States and Israel having a range of expertise that includes robotics, control, motor systems neuroscience and neurorehabilitation.

Getting the fingers to cooperate during dexterous manipulation requires the integration of different types of information. The fingers have a rich array of tactile sensors that generate signals related to the interaction with the object. However, for the brain to know the magnitude and direction of these forces, it must also know the orientation of the fingers in space. This information is obtained by other sources that form the basis for the sense of position of the body in space. The control of grasp can also be informed by kinesthetic force sensors in the muscles that in turn are integrated with the sense of the joint's configuration in space. This project takes advantage of a new technology that allows applying controlled stretches to the skin of the fingers. Skin stretch devices mounted on a robotic manipulator will be used to apply a variety of controlled perturbations while subjects are performing manipulation tasks. Perturbations will be applied to increase or decrease the consistency between tactile and kinesthetic feedback, and to investigate how the brain adapts the ability to maintain a stable grasp during both unpredictable and predictable forces. The approach will combine theory and experiments to tackle the integration of multiple information sources in perception and in controlling manipulation and grip forces.

This project is being supported by a partnership between the National Science Foundation and the U.S.-Israel Binational Science Foundation.

por.por_cntn:
A)   Nonlinear representation of kinematics

Towards efficient controllers for robotic prostheses, Alexandra (Sasha) Portnova, PhD student, created a nonlinear Auto Encoder (AE) network for compact representation of grasping trajectories. Analyses were performed on existing muscle activity data. Results indicate significant nonlinear features in movement and muscle activity data.

B)   Integration of kinesthetic and tactile information

1)    Mor Farajian, a PhD student, investigated the effects of adding artificial skin stretch to kinesthetic force on perception of stiffness and grip force adjustment. The skin-stretch increased the modulation of grip force in anticipation of the expected load. Moreover, the stretch causes an immediate illusion of touching a harder object.

2)    PhD student Hanna Kossowsky developed and experimentally validated a model for evaluating the relative impact  of tactile and movement information. She observed no effect of tactile variability, whereas the kinesthetic variability did increase perceptual uncertainty.

3)    To understand the dissociation between perception, manipulation, and grip force control, Masters student Natalie Ganz found that the accuracy of hand movement and of the grip force improved as stiffness increased, but the accuracy of perception decreased.

4)    PhD student Amit Milstein found that haptic force feedback, but not visual feedback, has a significant effect on the grip force-load force modulation.

5)    MSc student Shani Arusi looked into possible differences in perception and control of grip force between the hands. Results showed that right-handed participants perceived objects touched with the left hand to be stiffer than objects with their right hand.

6)    PhD student Chen Avraham investigated the effect of augmented tactile information on adaptation to force field. She found that if skin stretch is opposite to the field forces adaptation is more rapid and complete.

7)    In collaboration with colleagues in Italy an in Wisconsin we designed, developed, and tested a tactile stimulator and recorder. We obtained a first demonstration of the ability of this system to characterize tactile perception in healthy individuals and to quantify  tactile impairment in stroke survivors.

8)    MSc student Guy Biton at BGU, developed a new grip force measurement concept that allows for embedding tactile stimulation mechanisms in a gripper.

C) Effects of visuomotor delays on adaptation

9)    PhD student Chen Avraham tested transfer of adaptation to blind drawing, and found that adaptation to left delay or delay in both workspaces caused elongation of leftward movements. In contrast, adaptation to right delay caused elongation in both directions.

10) Postdoc Guy Avraham found that the effects of exposure to the delayed feedback transferred to blind reaching and tracking tasks and caused hypermetric movements.

11) Ali Farshchian, at the Shirley Ryan Ability Lab, found evidence suggesting that the sensory processes leading to the representation of the arm’s inertia are not continuous e but instead it takes place only during discrete, salient events.

12) With MSc student Erez Sulimani, Guy Avraham investigated how adaptation to delay affects the feedforward control of reaching movements and the proprioceptive assessment of hand location. In addition, he examined the importance of the target for the hypermetric reaching movements.

13) Raz Leib and Stephanie Hu, investigated the effect of handedness tendency and visual feedback on stiffness perception. They found that visual delays caused to slightly overestimate stiffness while force feedback delay caused a mixed effect on perception.
